    p62/SQSTM1, a Central but Unexploited Target: Advances in Its Physiological/Pathogenic Functions and Small Molecular Modulators

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    p62/SQSTM1, encoded by gene SQSTM1, is widely known as an adaptor protein of selective autophagy to promote aggregate-prone proteins for degradation. It is also a stress-induced scaffold protein involved in Nrf2 activation to resist oxidative stress. Multiple domains of p62 interact with several essential pathways implicated in cell differentiation and proliferation, placing p62 at a significant position to mediate cell survival and apoptosis. The p62 protein has been suggested as a potential target in recent years, since its abnormal expression or SQSTM1 gene mutation is tightly associated with various diseases including cancer such as hepatocellular carcinoma and prostate cancer, neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, atherosclerosis, and Paget’s disease of bone. In this review, we will discuss the relationship between p62 and these diseases, and we attempt to put forward novel methods for current diagnosis or therapy by regulating the p62 expression level.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In humans, p62/SQSTM1 is encoded by sequestosome 1(1) and is also called A170 and ZIP in mouse and rat, respectively.(2) p62/SQSTM1 is a stress-inducible scaffold protein, which has been recognized as a multifunctional signaling platform via regulating different domains involved in diverse cellular processes. p62 was initially isolated as an interacting partner of atypical protein kinase Cs(3) (aPKCs) or a signaling regulator residing in the late endosome–lysosome, but its emerging role as an adaptor protein of autophagy has received wide attention in recent years. This adaptor protein is not only located in the cytoplasm but also could be observed in the cell nucleus(4) and autophagy-related vesicles such as autophagosomes and lysosomes.(5) On the other hand, p62 is distributed in “cargoes”, waiting for degradation via autophagy or the ubiquitin–proteasome system (UPS). These obsoleting “cargoes” cover ubiquitin-marked misfolded protein aggregates, damaged, or senescent organelles,(6) and even invading pathogens.(7) Distribution of p62 in these “cargoes” lays a foundation and preparation for the subsequent selective autophagy.
    Although p62 is originally found as a central protein of regulating and impacting Paget’s disease of bone (PDB),(8) its central role of promoting cellular rubbish clearance is the most investigated. The central function of p62 is involved in the degradation of misfolded proteins through UPS or the autophagy-lysosome pathway. These two pathways are the major self-regulating systems to degrade misfolded protein aggregation and maintain the cellular homeostasis in eukaryotic cells. UPS is primarily responsible for the degradation of short-lived proteins and misfolded monomers,(9) while autophagy is devoted to removing long-lived proteins, misfolded oligomers, and impaired organelles.(10) Additionally, p62 is a substrate of the autophagy degradation system.(11) Despite the different labor division, UPS and autophagy interrelate closely and impact mutually. The loss of autophagy may do damage to UPS because p62 accumulation caused by autophagy deficiency delays the delivery of substrate to the proteasome.(12) Inversely, UPS inhibition leads to the elevation of autophagic activity via promoting p62 phosphorylation caused by proteotoxic stress.(13) p62 and UPS can also regulate the level of histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6), which influences the fusion of the autophagosome and lysosome.(14) Taken together, p62 is a bridge between UPS and autophagy, responsible for ubiquitinated protein degradation.
    Although p62 lacks inherent enzymatic activity, it acts as a multifunctional signaling hub by utilizing its various structural elements and regulating proteolytic pathways. These functions allow p62 to directly or indirectly interact with multifarious signaling pathways, which can control cell survival and death, inflammation, and metabolic reprogramming.(15) These imbalances are enough to induce multiple diseases including but not limited to osteoclastogenesis, immunopathy, neurodegeneration, tumorigenesis, and metabolic diseases. Here we discuss how p62 participates in processes of selective autophagy and other significant pathways associated with tumorigenesis, neurodegenerative diseases, atherosclerosis, and PDB. Then we enumerate existing available small-molecule modulators of the p62 protein and discuss its development prospect and possibilities as a potential target.

    2. p62 and Its Domain

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    p62, identified as a 62 kDa protein,(1) consists of six major domains (Figure 1): (1) an N-terminal Phox1 and Bem1p (PB1) domain; (2) a zinc finger (ZZ) domain, (3) a tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor 6 (TRAF6)-binding (TB) motif, (4) an LC3-interacting region (LIR) domain, (5) a Keap1-interacting region (KIR) domain, (6) a C-terminal ubiquitin-associated (UBA) domain.(16) Precisely because of these domains, p62 makes itself a multifunctional regulator involved in several physiological and pathological processes.
    The N-terminal PB1 domain is an evolutionarily conserved dimerization motif, which mediates protein homodimer and heterodimer formation.(17) p62 can self-assemble via the PB1 domain for dimerization and further oligomerization, which is critical for inclusion body formation and ubiquitinated protein accumulation.(18) p62 can also realize heter-dimerization with NBR1 and other signaling molecules containing PB1 domains, such as aPKCs and mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase 3 (MEKK3).(19) Both aPKCs and MEKK3 regulate nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB) activation,(17) which is involved in inflammation and immunity. Thus, the PB1 domain is significant for the protein–protein interaction, and the dysfunction of this region will lead to the failure of activating the NF-κB pathway and p62-dependent selective autophagy.
    The ZZ zinc finger domain of p62 functions to bind to the receptor-interacting protein (RIP, a TNFα signaling adaptor). Through interacting with RIP, p62 acts as an intermediate in the NF-κB signaling pathway combined with aPKCs.(17) This domain is accounted for as a regulator of inflammation and cell death.(20) Yan et al. demonstrated that the absence of the ZZ domain restored the sensitivity of ovarian cancer cells to cisplatin treatment, which proposed that the ZZ domain is associated with drug resistance by inhibiting cell death.(21) Besides, the G155L mutation of this region is predicted to be pathogenic to ALS reported by Kwok et al.(22)
    The TB domain of p62 is responsible for regulating the level of TRAF6 and trigger protein polyubiquitination. TRAF6 is a lysine 63 E3 ubiquitin ligase and promotes K63 polyubiquitination of specific substrates including itself.(23) The TB domain of p62 interacts with TRAF6 and enhances its ubiquitin ligase activity by inducing polyubiquitination and oligomerization.(24) In addition, p62 participates in activating the NF-κB signaling pathway to promote the expression of inflammatory genes in conjunction with TRAF6.(17) The TB domain is reported to influence osteoclastogenesis,(25) neurodegenerative diseases,(26) and Ras-induced tumorigenesis.(27)
    The LIR domain of p62 is required for the autophagy degradation of mammalian proteins, which ensures the targeting of autophagy receptors to light chain 3 (LC3) or other autophagy gene 8 (ATG8) family proteins anchored in the phagophore membrane.(28) p62 interacts with LC3 through its LIR domain to promote the formation of autophagosomes and deliver polyubiquitinated “cargoes” to autophagic degradation.(29) In addition, p62 can also interact with other autophagic effector proteins like beclin-1, γ-aminobutyric acid receptor-associated protein (GABARAP), and GABARAP-like molecules through the LIR domain.(30) The interaction of LC3 and this domain is a key procedure of selective autophagy. Dysfunction of the LIR domain will result in the failure of p62-induced autophagy, which can aggravate the accumulation of damaged proteins in neurodegenerative diseases.
    The KIR domain is related to nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) activation under normal conditions. Nrf2 is a basic-leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor and is responsible for the gene expression of antioxidant elements (AREs) and detoxifying enzymes to respond to oxidative stress and inflammation.(31) Keap1 is a critical medium to negatively regulate the expression of Nrf2 by promoting its ubiquitination, resulting in the rapid degradation of Nrf2 by UPS.(32) Under abnormal conditions, p62 can stabilize Nrf2 activation in response to oxidative stress through its KIR domain.(33) p62 competes with Nrf2 to interact with Keap1 for autophagic degradation, leading to Nrf2–Keap1 dissociation and Nrf2-translocation to the nucleus. Then Nrf2 will induce the transcription of detoxification enzymes and AREs.(34) From another perspective, p62 accumulation might result in the continuous activation of Nrf2 and have a detrimental effect. p62–Keap1 complexes were detected in many neoplastic cells as well as some neurodegenerative disorders.(35)
    The C-terminal UBA domain of p62 can bind to ubiquitinated protein aggregates and regulate the interaction between ubiquitinated proteins and autophagosomes.(36) This process is an important part of ubiquitinated proteins degradation via the autophagy-lysosomal pathway. Additionally, mutations of the UBA domain are observed in both familiar ALS and PDB patients confirmed by Teyssou et al.(37) Chamoux et al. also reported that mutations in the UBA region activate TRAF6-NF-κB signaling, contributing to increased osteoclastogenesis, which might be the direct cause of PDB.(25)
    Besides the six main domains, there are two nuclear localization signals (NLS1/2) and a nuclear export signal (NES) responsible for the nucleo-cytoplasmic shuttling of p62. p62 can shuttle continuously between the nucleus and cytoplasm via its NLSs and NES.(38) p62 is involved in the accumulation of nuclear polyubiquitinated proteins in promyelocytic leukemia bodies through inhibiting the export of nuclear proteins. Pankiv et al. suggested that p62 may also function to transport ubiquitinated “cargoes” from the nucleus to the cytosol for degradation.(38)

    3. p62 and Selective Autophagy

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Autophagy, the literal meaning is “self-eating”, collaborates with apoptosis (cell “self-killing”) to regulate cell survival and death.(39) However, the internal cooperation and conversion mechanisms between them are not entirely clear. Autophagy is a highly conserved process and generally preserved among different species and cell types (including tumor cells) for its contribution to cell survival.(40) It is essential for cells to maintain a basic and low level of autophagy activity to maintain the stabilization of homeostasis because multifarious kinds of “garbage” produced by cells, such as broken organelles and misfolded proteins, need to be removed in time.(10) Autophagy is able to maintain cell self-stability and devoted to degrading or removing this “garbage”. Furthermore, breakdown products of autophagy, such as fatty acids and amino acids, can be reused by cells to provide energy and build new proteins.(41)
    There are three types of autophagy classified by the generation process: macroautophagy, microautophagy, and chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA).(42) Macroautophagy (hereinafter referred to as autophagy) is the most studied type, which is generally characterized by the formation of a cup-shaped phagophore with a double-layer membrane.(43) Microautophagy is a process where lysosomes are active to phagocytose cytoplasmic components directly.(44) Some molecular chaperones, such as the heat shock cognate chaperone of 70 kDa (Hsp70), are requisite for CMA. Molecular chaperones play significant roles in the translocation of unfolded proteins into the lysosomal membrane.(45) Autophagy maintains a low level under normal cellular conditions, but it will be activated by several inducing factors including intracellular and extracellular stimulation. Intracellular stimulation contains metabolic stress, misfolded or aggregated proteins, and aging or damaged organelles. Extracellular stimulation includes nutrition deficiency, oxygen deficit, and growth factor concentration withdrawal.(46) Once these inductive signals are accepted by cells, autophagy-related proteins will be synthesized in quantity to prepare for autophagy. Then it forms a cup-shaped double-membrane structure named phagophore in the cytoplasm and expands continuously. Phagophores can be observed under the electron microscope directly, which is regarded as the ironclad evidence of autophagy initiation. Phagophores keep expanding, and cytoplasmic components, such as mitochondria, ribosomes, and endoplasmic reticulum fragments, will be sequestered into the “cup”. Then phagophores close the opening and form a sealed spherical autophagosome, which can also be observed under an electron microscope. The rapid mass formation of autophagosomes is a significant symbol of autophagy performance. Autolysosomes are formed by merging autophagosomes and lysosomes, where “cargoes” will be degraded. The inner membrane of autophagosomes is degraded by lysosomal enzymes to promote fusion during this period. The degradation products will be transported to the cytoplasm for reuse, while the residue will be expelled from the cell or remain in the cytoplasm (Figure 2).(47) Autophagy is a batch degradation process, and its emergency characteristic allows cells to quickly adapt to severe environments. Autophagy has two main cellular functions: detoxification through removing cellular waste and conferring resistance to nutritional stress.(48) Although autophagy is beneficial to cell survival under adverse conditions including metabolic stress and cellular damage, it must be stopped in time after a crisis-resolution; otherwise, its powerful ability to capture and degrade cytoplasmic components will lead to irreversible cell damage.
    Precisely because of the emergency feature and batch degradation pattern, autophagy has been characterized as a nonselective bulk degradation pathway induced by nutrient deprivation or other stress situations for a long time. Nevertheless, a growing body of evidence has demonstrated that autophagy also contributes to selectively degrading superfluous or damaged mitochondria (mitophagy),(49) protein aggregates (aggrephagy),(50) invading bacteria or viruses (xenophagy),(51) peroxisomes (pexophagy),(52) and ribosomes (ribophagy).(53) Selective autophagy is devoted to clearing abnormal organelles and protein aggregates, which are frequently pathological features of several diseases, especially neurodegenerative and metabolic diseases. Lamark et al. reported that, during the selective autophagy process, p62 functions as a “cargo” receptor of the degradation of ubiquitinated target substrates.(54) Intracellular protein aggregates to be degraded are labeled by ubiquitination along with p62 appearance. For example, p62 has been found in ubiquitinated protein inclusions, such as neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) of AD and Mallory bodies (MBs) of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).(55) p62 can promote the selective autophagy process by interacting with both ubiquitinated substrates and LC3 through its UBA and LIR domain, respectively.
    Since selective autophagy plays an important role in physiological or pathological processes, it is necessary to detect its level for fear of malfunction. LC3 is a recognized marker of autophagy. LC3-I (cytoplasmic LC3) will lose a small polypeptide through enzymolysis and translate to LC3-II (autophagosome membrane type) during autophagy occurrence.(56) Therefore, it is a viable method to evaluate the level of autophagy, which is usually called autophagy flux, by measuring the ratio of LC3-II/LC3-I under the condition of autophagy inhibitor or activator treatment. In addition, the level of p62 could reflect the level of autophagy due to the fact that p62 can be degraded as an autophagic substrate through its LIR domain binding to LC3.(57) In the experiment of detecting autophagy flux by p62, effects of lysosomal activity and gene expression should also be considered. Autophagy flux can also reflect the expression of p62, and autophagy is an important factor in the control of the level of p62.(58) Suppression or decline of autophagy is always accompanied by the accumulation of p62. However, p62 expression is not only merely mediated by selective autophagic degradation but also regulated by UPS, which is responsible for nonselective degradation. The inhibition of UPS enhances p62 transcription as well as the accumulation of ubiquitinated proteins.(59) Besides, the SQSTM1 gene transcriptional regulation is also positively stimulated by compound induction and oxidative stress associated with Nrf2. A high level of p62 or proteasome deficiency promotes the activation of Nrf2(55) and elevated Nrf2 expression also results in the transcriptional activation of the SQSTM1 gene in return, further inducing p62 synthesis through a feed-forward loop.
    It is generally considered that p62 is not only a substrate but also a “cargo” receptor for the autophagic degradation of ubiquitinated protein aggregates. Although the negative correlation between autophagy and this adaptor protein has been manifested, how p62 functions in recognizing selective autophagy substrates against ordinary “cargoes” should be deeper studied and investigated. Dysfunction of autophagy causes up-regulation of p62 and p62-containing protein aggregates, which are usually associated with neurodegenerative diseases and oncogenesis.(26) The connection between p62 accumulation and disease occurrence or development will be clearly demonstrated in the following paragraphs.

    4. p62 and Tumorigenesis

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cell death and survival are two significant aspects of metabolism to maintain normal physiological activity, once blocking the balance will contribute to the occurrence of various diseases including cancer. Tumorigenesis, characterized by excessive proliferation, is a consequence of sequential mutations in genes regulating cell growth and proliferation.(2) Aberrant expression of p62 has been implicated in multiple forms of cancer such as human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC),(60) pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC),(61) and prostate cancer (PCa).(62) The relationship between p62 and different types of cancer is complex, and sometimes even contradictory. Growing lines of evidence reveal that p62 accumulation in epithelial cells is a necessary and sufficient condition to induce tumorigenesis and deterioration without other extra carcinogen stimuli,(63) independent of its functions associated with autophagy. In other words, the level of p62 expression is proportional to tumor formation, and p62 is regarded as an oncogenic protein for its overexpression in vivo. However, the negative impacts of p62 up-regulation are not absolute in the process of the tumor. Valencia et al. reported that the down-regulation of p62 in the stroma of several tumors, especially in cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), is suggested as a potential contribution to promoting cancer progression.(64) Here, p62 acts as a noncell-autonomous tumor suppressor by reducing inflammation in the tumor microenvironment.(65) Indeed, p62 dysfunction is relative to not only tumor formation and promotion but also drug resistance of therapy. Therefore, it is necessary to discuss the dual role of p62 in tumorigenesis, respectively, from different angles.

    4.1. p62 as a Tumor Activator

    Multifunctional functions of p62 make itself a potential regulator of tumorigenesis through interacting with pathways responsible for controlling the cell anabolism and catabolism. p62 accumulation contributes to cancer progression mainly through five approaches (Figure 3): (1) selective autophagy, (2) the NF-κB signaling pathway, (3) the Nrf2 pathway, (4) the mechanistic target of the rapamycin (mTOR) pathway, (5) the oncogenic transcription factor Twist1 pathway.

    4.1.1. Autophagy Dysfunction

    Eskelinen pointed out that autophagy plays a dual role in tumorigenesis.(66) During the initial stage of tumorigenesis, autophagy functions as a tumor suppressor through eliminating damaged organelles, alleviating oxidative stress, and promoting oncogene-induced senescence.(67) On the contrary, once the cancer has established, autophagy is pro-tumorigenic to protect cancer cells from metabolic stress, inflammation, chemotherapy-induced stresses,(68) and anoikis.(69) Either autophagy suppressing or promoting tumor development depends on the cancer subtype and the stage of tumor development.(70) p62 is a specific autophagy substrate and fails to be normally degraded by autophagy deficiency in the tumor, which causes the accumulation of p62.(71) Elevated p62 expression is associated with degenerated protein aggregate accumulation and production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), inducing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and DNA damage.(66) These detrimental phenomena, as well as persistent activation, of Nrf2 are usually observed in autophagy impairment caused by the loss of Atg5 or Atg7 (Atg5–/– or Atg7–/–) in mouse liver, ultimately leading to HCC and other liver tumors.(72) Loss of p62 or Nrf2 is also found to succeed in suppressing tumor development in aforementioned animal models.(73) Additionally, Moscat et al. proposed that p62-positive aggregates impact on cell survival by activating the NF-κB pathway and cell death by caspase-activated apoptosis.(74) Taken together, p62 functions as an oncogenic protein to promote tumorigenesis in autophagy-defective cells and animals. It reveals a potential therapy for tumors through activating autophagy to promote p62 accumulation and degrade protein aggregates for clearance and degradation in the early stage of cancer. Nevertheless, it is noteworthy that autophagy is observed to be up-regulated in many Ras-induced cancer cell lines, and Ras-expressing Atg5–/– or Atg7–/– cells displayed tumor inhibition in mice compared to the control group.(75) For example, malignant melanoma survives from anticancer treatments by activating autophagy to overcome drug-induced stress or cytotoxicity(76) and is prevented from anoikis, which may promote metastasis.(69) For the pro-tumorigenic function of autophagy in Ras-induced cancer, it is suggested that inhibiting autophagy can augment anticancer activity and chemosensitivity in combination with conventional chemotherapy.(77) The dual identity of autophagy in tumor reflects the significance of targeted therapy.

    4.1.2. NF-κB Pathway Activation

    The NF-κB pathway is a critical regulator of inflammation and the immune response involved in cellular survival.(78) NF-κB signaling cascade induction has been regarded as a distinguishing feature of several tumors.(79) Activation of the NF-κB pathway is involved in promoting tumorigenesis from three aspects.(80) Initially, NF-κB activation promotes the production of ROS to induce DNA damage and oncogenic mutations. Then it promotes the proliferation and differentiation of tumor cells, meanwhile preventing Ras-induced cell death from p53-independent apoptosis.(23) Finally, NF-κB activation-induced inflammation speeds cancer deterioration and metastasis by stimulating the expression of genes responsible for promoting neoangiogenesis and cancer cell invasion.(81) p62 interacts with TRAF6 to activate NF-κB activation via proinflammatory cytokines including interleukin-1 (IL-1),(82) tumor necrosis factor (TNF),(83) and nerve growth factor (NGF) receptors.(24) Recent studies have confirmed that the function of p62 in NF-κB activation is relevant in tumorigenesis such as lung cancer and PDAC.(84) Oncogenic Ras mutations are usually detected in a variety of human cancers and draw wide attention in the research of cancer. Ras is indispensable for cancer initiation and progression for its function of promoting cell survival.(75) Oncogenic transformation is abolished by the ablation of p62 in the endogenous Ras-induced lung cancer model, revealing p62 as a central player in Ras-induced carcinogenesis.(61) A feed-forward loop between p62, NF-κB, and Ras has been illuminated to promote tumor cell survival in PDAC development.(84) Ras activates NF-κB by stimulating signal transduction cascades;(85) NF-κB then transcriptionally induces p62 up-regulation, which is necessary for Ras to trigger IkB kinase (IKK) and leads to further NF-κB activation in return. Once an element of this loop is disturbed, the vicious circle will be blocked and contributes to increased cell death and decreased tumorigenicity. Ras-dependent carcinogenesis development is also positively related to autophagy expression. The Ras-induced tumor is prevented by interfering with both autophagosome formation caused by autophagy deficiency and “cargo” delivery to autophagosomes caused by p62 depletion.(75) Autophagy disruption by FIP200 (FAK family interacting protein of 200 kDa, an essential autophagy-related protein)(86) deletion inhibits the growth of established tumors, and knockdown/knockout of p62 in established FIP200-null tumors further impedes tumor growth.(87) Wei et al. concluded that p62 can synergize with autophagy to obstacle established tumors growth, providing a new insight that inhibition of both p62 accumulation and autophagy up-regulation may be more effective than targeting alone for Ras-induced cancer therapy. (Figure 3).

    4.1.3. Nrf2 Pathway Activation

    Oxidative stress caused by overproduction of ROS leads to cellular damage and promotes cell death.(88) The Nrf2–Keap1 pathway has been reported to function as a crucial cellular defense mechanism against electrophilic and oxidative stresses.(89) Persistent activation of Nrf2 has been found in autophagy-deficient tumor cells as well as p62 accumulation. It has been demonstrated that overexpression of p62 increases the levels of nuclear Nrf2, ARE-luciferase, and NAD(P)H dehydrogenase quinone 1 (a target antioxidative response gene).(90) Nrf2 is a key transcription factor responsible for gene expression of cytoprotective enzymes, antioxidant proteins, and phase II detoxifying enzymes to neutralize ROS and restore cellular redox balance.(91) On the other hand, persistent activation Nrf2 leads to cell excessive proliferation, usually existing in uncontrolled inflammation and tumorigenesis. Keap1 is a substrate adaptor protein of a Cullin 3 (Cul3)-based ubiquitin ligase and functions to maintain a low level of Nrf2 by promoting its ubiquitination and degradation in 26S proteasome under normal conditions (Figure 4).(92) Upon induction of ROS, Nrf2 is activated to protect cells from oxidative stress through the canonical and noncanonical mechanism. In the canonical pathway, Keap1/Cul3-mediated Nrf2 degradation is blocked through modification of cysteine residues in Keap1, resulting in Nrf2 escaping from Keap1-induced ubiquitination and activation of the Nrf2-dependent cytoprotective gene. In addition to the canonical pathway, Nrf2 activation can also be achieved by several endogenous proteins such as p62 and p21, functioning as a noncanonical way to disturb the Nrf2–Keap1 interaction (Figure 5).(93) The KIR domain of p62 competitively binds to the Kelch domain of Keap1, which is the same binding site of Nrf2, resulting in the dissociation of the Nrf2–Keap1 complex and activation of Nrf2 to induce the expression of ARE-bearing genes.(94) Increased Nrf2 expression also results in the transcriptional activation of the SQSTM1 gene and increasing further p62 accumulation in turn. The positive correlation between p62 accumulation and constitutive activation of Nrf2 constitutes a feed-forward loop, which promotes cancer cell survival against various stresses caused by oxidative damage or anticancer agents. Saito T et al. reported that the accumulation of p62 is sufficient to induce the development of HCC, and cancer cells are conferred with enhanced proliferation ability and anticancer resistance through sustained Nrf2 activation.(95) However, it should be pointed out that Nrf2 up-regulation is harmful to tumor treatment for its excessive reproductive capacity, but it plays a protective role in normal or damaged cells. This reminds us of the importance to develop target therapy of cancer: devoted not only to inhibit abnormal tumor cell growth but also to ensure normal cells are free from harm. It is a potential therapeutic to design and exploit p62 targeting inhibitors to reducing the overexpression of p62 and down-regulation of Nrf2 to suppress cancer cell survival and growth.

    4.1.4. mTOR Pathway Activation

    mTOR, belonging to the PI3K-related kinase family, is a serine/threonine protein kinase. It is a part of two distinct protein complexes in mammalian cells: mTOR complex 1 (mTORC1, consisted of mTOR, Raptor, and GβL proteins) and mTOR complex 2 (mTORC2, consisted of mTOR, Rictor, mSin1, GβL, and Protor).(96) mTORC1 is an important promoter of protein synthesis and cell growth, which is usually overexpressed in tumorigenesis.(3) Actually, up-regulation of mTORC1 highly accelerates cancer process by impacting on both anabolism and catabolism.(75) This complex is beneficial to enhance cancer cell growth by stimulating the production of protein, lipid, and nucleotide, simultaneously inhibiting catabolic pathways such as autophagy.(97) p62 has been reported to be an anti-inflammatory tumor suppressor through its regulation of the mTORC1 pathway in epithelial prostate cancer cells.(64) This signaling adapter is considered as a nutrient sensor for the activation of the mTORC1 pathway in response to amino acids by interacting with Raptor and the Rags proteins.(98) p62 can be phosphorylated at Thr269 and Ser272 by mitogen-activated protein kinase 3/6 (MEK3/6) and p38 delta and is driven by the PB1-containing kinase MEKK3 under amino acid stimulation.(99) Then p62 interacts with Raptor, Rag proteins, and the E3-ubiquitin ligase TRAF6 to recruit mTORC1 to the lysosomal membrane and catalyze mTOR polyubiquitination. Finally, the ubiquitination driven by p62-TRAF6 under amino acid-rich conditions results in mTORC1 activation, followed by increased anabolism capacity and cell growth.(100) Taken together, aberrant p62 accumulation is a critical component of the mTORC1 activation in multiple human cancers, suggesting that the p62-mTORC1 cassette may be a potential target to delay cancer development. Inhibitors of p62 or mTORC1 are expected to function as suppressors of tumorigenesis. For instance, Sapanisertib is an effective oral adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-dependent mTORC1 inhibitor via exhibiting an enzymatic inhibition activity against mTOR, and it has been applied in clinical practice to anticancer.(101) In addition, kinase MEKK3 inhibitors should be designed in the future for its pivotal role in p62 phosphorylation, which is required for mTORC1 activation.

    4.1.5. Twist1 Stabilization

    Twist1 is a core oncogenic transcription factor in regulating both early embryonic morphogenesis and cancer development and metastasis.(102) It promotes the propagation and migration of cancer cells by inhibiting epithelial-cadherin(103) and facilitating epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).(102) Under normal circumstances, Twist1 can be degraded by both autophagy and proteasome systems. However, in autophagy-defective tumor cells, the UBA domain of p62 binds to ubiquitinated Twist1 and blocks the natural degradation of this regulator to stabilize Twist1.(103) Besides preventing Twist1 from degradation, p62 is also required for Twist1 up-regulation and epithelial-cadherin down-regulation in EMT induced by the epidermal growth factor (EGF)/transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β). Of note, researchers have demonstrated that p62 only promotes cancer cell propagation and migration in the presence of oncogenic protein Twist1 by conducting xenograft mouse models.(104) Therefore, blocking the stabilization of Twist1 induced by p62 accumulation may be a possible therapeutic strategy for the treatment of autophagy-deficient tumors. The drug combination of autophagy activators and p62 inhibitors may improve the situation of Twist1 overexpression in cancer, by promoting its clearance and inhibiting its proliferation, respectively.

    4.2. p62 as a Tumor Suppressor

    The contents above highlighted the positive correlation between p62 accumulation and cancer progression. However, Valencia et al. reported that p62 sometimes serves as an anti-inflammatory tumor suppressor in the stroma of several tumors.(64) For example, in human PCa, p62 is expressed in both prostate epithelium and the stroma. It is noticeable that p62 levels have been shown to increase in the epithelial compartment of the PCa, while down-regulated in the tumor stroma compared to the normal stroma.(64) Besides genetic alterations within the epithelial compartment, the tumor microenvironment also attracts attention gradually for its critical role in neoplasias progression.(105) Although pathways between the stromal and epithelial compartments are little researched, it is imaginable that the metabolic state of the tumor stroma has a nonnegligible influence on the oncogenic capacity of the tumor epithelial compartment.(106) Loss of p62 in stromal cells triggers inflammation and metabolism dysfunction, which are two critical factors contributing to the tumorigenic properties of the stroma. CAFs are activated during tumor progression, as key mediators between malignant cells and the microenvironment.(107) p62 deficiency in the stromal fibroblasts results in decreased mTORC1 activity, further triggering an inflammatory response. CAFs can be activated by inflammation and enhance tumor cell proliferation and invasion. Interleukin-6 (IL-6), as a proinflammatory factor, has been implicated as a key proinflammatory and protumorigenic molecule in many tumors including PCa. p62 deficiency in the PCa stroma accelerates prostate tumorigenesis in different mouse models,(64) suggesting that p62 functions as a tumor suppressor in the tumor microenvironment.(108) There are at least three methods for p62 to serve as an anti-inflammation and anticancerogenesis factor (Figure 6). p62 inhibits IL-6 activation in fibroblastic stromal cells by repressing ROS production.(64) It has been described before that both NF-κB and Nrf2 pathways can be activated by p62 and protect cells from oxidative stress induced by ROS. Up-regulation of p62 can also activate the mTOR1 pathway to inhibit CAFs activation and blocking inflammation. p62 is a key regulator of c-malignancy myelocytomatosis (c-Myc), which is responsible for glutamine and glucose metabolism.(7) It is a novel method to combine epithelial-targeted therapies with target stromal activation by enhancement of p62 expression or inhibition of inflammation.
    The signaling adaptor p62 protein is involved in tumorigenesis through sophisticated pathways. It is overexpressed in cancer epithelial cells, while deficient in the tumor microenvironment, particularly in CAFs. The dual role of p62 suggests different potential therapeutic strategies for cancer under different conditions. For instance, the overexpression of p62 can serve as a novel prognostic marker for several tumors, such as epithelial ovarian cancer(109) and lung cancer. However, p62 activators are expected to apply in activating the tumor stroma to delay cancer development. As a whole, drug targeting should be taken into full consideration to avoid possible side effects in normal cells when designing or developing anticarcinogens.

    5. p62 and Neurodegenerative Diseases

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Neurodegenerative diseases are syndromes marked by progressive death of neurons in the brain and spinal cord, resulting in the decline of cognitive ability and behavior disorder. Neurodegenerative diseases mainly include Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Parkinson’s disease (PD), Huntington’s disease (HD), and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).(110)

    5.1. p62 and AD

    AD, the most common form of neurodegenerative disorders, is characterized by memory loss, cognitive impairment, and behavioral abnormalities.(111) Two predominant pathological hallmarks of AD are extracellular β-amyloid (Aβ) neuritic plaques (NPs) and intraneuronal NFTs occurring in the entorhinal cortex and hippocampus, which are both immediate consequences of the destruction of synapses along with loss of working memory and neuronal apoptosis.(112) Besides misfolded protein aggregates, both damaged mitochondria and oxidative stress are relevant to AD, PD, and HD.(113) AD-like lesions were detected in both the hippocampus and cortex of the knock out mice (p62–/–) brain, corresponding to wild-type mice.(114) Actually, p62 can be considered as a potential target to treat or delay AD via at least three methods: (1) promoting clearance of toxic protein aggregates; (2) regulating the degraded function of mitophagy; (3) relieving oxidative stress (Figure 7).

    5.1.1. Misfolded Proteins Clearance

    The accumulation of misfolded proteins has been revealed as a hallmark of AD by damaging the balance of protein homeostasis and causing neurotoxicity.(115) Under normal conditions, misfolded malfunctioning proteins can be removed by three protective mechanisms classified by molecular size: UPS for misfolded monomer, the autophagy-lysosome pathway for most misfolded oligomers, and inclusion body formation for large oligomers.(116) Ubiquitin makes it an important impact in all three ways, since it marks toxic proteins for different forms of degradation. The UBA domain of p62 binds to ubiquitin-modified proteins and shuttles them to the proteasomal or autophagosomal pathways for degradation via the PB1 or LIR domain, respectively.(117) NFTs pathology in AD contains accumulated hyperphosphorylated polyubiquitinated tau, which is initially discovered as a major microtubule-associated protein found in the axons of neurons. Tau is a K63-polyubiquitinated TRAF6 substrate that interacts with the UBA domain of p62 and is targeted for proteasomal degradation.(118) Decline of p62 expression in AD makes p62 unable to shuttle polyubiquitinated tau for clearance and contributes to the accumulation of aggregated polyubiquitinated tau. Besides disturbing ubiquitinated tau degradation, p62 absence is also directly related to tau-hyperphosphorylation,(114) which promotes abnormal aggregation of misfolded tau with decreased binding to microtubules.(119) Hopefully, the elevation of the p62 level is beneficial to remove aggregated polyubiquitinated tau and in favor of reversing AD pathologic courses. Another major lesion characteristic of AD is the abundant deposition of Aβ in senile plaques of brain tissue.(120) The Aβ peptide is a proteolytic fragment, containing 39–43 amino acids, derived by the β- and γ-secretase cleavage of the transmembrane amyloid precursor protein (APP).(121) Overproduction and accumulation of Aβ contribute to early onset familial AD (EOFAD).(122) Failure to remove Aβ deposits from NPs results in late-onset AD (LOAD).(123) The imbalance between production and clearance of Aβ damages the neuronal homeostasis in the brain, accompanied by progressive synaptic dysfunction and neuritic injury. Geetha et al. reported that p62 cooperating with TRAF6 inhibits Aβ-mediated neuronal death through the p75 neurotrophin receptor (p75NTR, a member of the TNF receptor superfamily).(121) NGF is a specific ligand binding to p75NTR and induces polyubiquitination to promote cell survival and differentiation.(124) TRAF6 and p62 are essential for p75NTR polyubiquitination upon NGF stimulation since TRAF6 functions to polyubiquitinate substrates and p62 enhances the ubiquitin ligase activity of TRAF6, while p75NTR recruits TRAF6/p62 to activate the NF-κB pathway to mediate cell survival.(125) However, Aβ can also interact with p75NTR to induce neuronal cell death by impairing the polyubiquitination process dependent on TRAF6/p62.(125) It is a potential therapeutic approach to enhance TRAF6/p62 expression for that they are capable of relieving the Aβ-mediated inhibition of p75NTR polyubiquitination and restoring neuronal cells survival.

    5.1.2. Mitophagy Regulation

    Mitochondria are referred to as the “powerhouses” of cells, which are the primary producers of cellular energy currency ATP and a major source of ROS.(126) Mitophagy, one form of the selective autophagic pathway, functions as a selective scavenger to degrade impaired or superfluous mitochondria.(49) Mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis are two sides to control mitochondrial homeostasis essential for cellular function and survival.(127) Nevertheless, mitophagy balance is compromised in AD neurological pathologies, which subsequently induces damaged mitochondria accumulation resulting in reduced cellular ATP levels and excessive ROS production.(128) Mattson et al. reported that superfluous ROS generated by altering mitochondria can also promote the accumulation of polyubiquitinated tau aggregates.(129) Additionally, increased ROS generation causes oxidative stress, a function of ROS defenses, resulting in increased γ-secretase activity to accelerate Aβ production and deposition in neurons.(130) Although mitophagy is regarded to be closely correlated with neurodegeneration, its explicit mechanism has not been elucidated. One of the most studied theories is that mitophagy is mediated by PTEN-induced putative kinase protein 1 (PINK1, a mitochondria-targeted serine/threonine kinase) and Parkin (a subunit of ubiquitin E3 ligase) in mammalian cells.(131) Once mitochondrial damage occurs, the inner membrane potential disappears and leads to the dimerization and cross-phosphorylation of PINK1. Subsequently, Parkin is recruited by PINK1 to mitochondria, and the increased E3 ubiquitin ligase activity of Parkin contributes to the induction of mitophagy. In this process, p62 binds to Parkin-ubiquitinated mitochondrial substrates and mediates the accumulation of mitochondria reported by Ding et al.(132) The relationship between PINK1, Parkin, and p62 can be summarized as the mitochondrial translocation of Parkin is controlled by functional PINK1,(133) while functional Parkin is a prerequisite for the recruitment function of p62 to clustered mitochondria.(134) Even so, it is still controversial about the involvement of p62 in PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy. Geisler et al. found that the knockdown of SQSTM1 resulted in the failure of mitochondrial clearance compared with the control.(134) Park et al. also reported that p62 can interact with choline dehydrogenase (CHDH) to recruit LC3 to impaired or superfluous mitochondria and then stimulate mitophagy.(135) The above research proved that p62 is required for PINK1/Parkin-dependent mitophagy and essential for the final mitochondrial clearance.(134) However, several recent studies dispute the nonsubstitutable position of p62 in mitophagy. Hollville et al. suggested that NBR1 can replace p62 to mediate mitophagy in the cytosol.(136) Lazarou et al. knocked out five autophagy receptors (TAX1BP1, NDP52, NBR1, p62, and Optineurin) in HeLa cells to clarify the function of receptors during mitophagy. They manifested that both p62 and NBR1 are the dispensable receptors for PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy.(137) Calvo-Garrido et al. reported that p62 is not required for mitochondrial removal, and p62 absence is unrelated to mitophagy deficiency in neuroepithelial stem cells (NESCs).(138) Haack et al. pointed out that p62 is involved in Parkin-induced mitochondrial clustering but is unnecessary for mitochondrial clearance.(139) Given the above, mitophagy can occur through a p62-independent method, and p62 is dispensable for mitophagy itself. Even though the irreplaceable position of p62 is controversial in PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy, it is generally considered that p62 is associated with the perinuclear clustering of depolarized mitochondria and managing mitochondria quality control (MQC) through selective “cargo” recognition.(140) Up-regulation of the p62 level to enhance the interaction between p62 and Parkin might be favorable for rebalancing mitophagy to recover normal degradation function.

    5.1.3. Oxidative Stress Alleviation

    Oxidative stress, an immediate consequence of ROS over generation, is a significant risk factor associated with AD as well as other aging-related diseases.(141) Products of lipid and nucleic acid oxidation such as malondialdehyde (MDA), 4-hydroxynonenal (4-HNE),(142) and 8-hydroxyguanosine (8-OHG)(143) can be perceived as diagnostic biomarkers for early AD because they have been confirmed to express elevated levels in mild cognitive impairment (MCI). In the AD pathological process, oxidative stress may be induced by multiple mechanisms including inflammation, metal accumulation, hyperphosphorylated tau, and mitochondrial dysfunction mentioned before.(144) Antioxidants, such as Mitoquinone (MitoQ)(145) and curcumin,(146) may be used for exerting neuron protection in AD by eliminating ROS and preventing oxidative damage. Oxidative stress can also directly damage the promoter region of p62, as an oxidative stress-induced protein,(144) and inhibit the transcriptional activity of the p62 promoter via oxidative modification of the Sp-1 (an amplicon within human p62 promoter) transcription factor binding site.(147) Increased p62 expression competitively binding to Keap1 can stimulate Nrf2 to activate ARE-driven gene translation in response to oxidative stress through creating a positive feedback loop between p62 up-regulation and Nrf2 activation.(148) However, several studies proved that the Keap1-Nrf2-ARE pathway can be inducted by a p62-independent method. Valencia et al. claimed that no changes of Keap1 and Nrf2 occurred in p62-deficient stromal fibroblasts. Kwon et al. also found that the Nrf2 pathway was still activated in p62–/– mice. The Keap1–Nrf2 interaction may be blocked by other means besides binding to the KIR domain. Although the uniqueness of p62 is uncertain in this process, increased p62 expression is conducive to activating the Keap1–Nrf2–ARE pathway. Moreover, p62 itself may be capable of sensing the oxygen concentration directly, like an oxygen sensor.(138) Carroll et al. reported that two oxygen-sensing cysteine residues (C105 and C113) of p62 promote activation of autophagy in response to ROS-induced oxidative stress.(149) p62 is able to sense the saturation of ROS, and the redox-sensitivity of p62 might be involved in facilitating efficient autophagy to maintain cellular homeostasis.(149) Logically, the up-regulation of p62 is a potential defense against oxidative stress to maintain cell viability. The aforementioned deletion of the Sp-1 binding site could activate p62 through abolishing the damage of the oxidative stress-modified promoter, but this complicated method to activate p62 is infeasible in clinical use.

    5.2. p62 and ALS/FTD

    Although P62 accumulation promotes AD pathology progression, several missense mutations of SQSTM1 have also been identified in patients with other adult-onset neurodegenerative diseases including ALS and frontotemporal dementia (FTD).(150) ALS is a motor neuron disease characterized by the degeneration of the brain and spinal cord motor neurons and progressive muscle weakness, finally leading to muscle paralysis.(151) Kwok et al. sequenced the SQSTM1 gene in a cohort of 61 familial ALS patients, and the P392L and G155L mutations were predicted to be pathogenic.(22) The P392L mutation in the UBA region is present in both familiar ALS and PDB, indicating a common pathogenic mechanism between ALS and PDB. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is the third most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia, after AD and PD.(152) Compared with the progressive muscle paralysis of ALS, FTD affects brain regions and leads to dementia. Kunikazu et al. identified that p62 is involved in degrading the 43 kDa transactive response-DNA-binding protein (TDP-43, existing in most FTD cases).(153) ALS and FTD belong to the same clinicopathological spectrum despite different clinical symptoms. Many patients even suffer from both ALS and FTD simultaneously.(154) p62 mediates the progression of ALS/FTD through three possible methods: the Keap1–Nrf2–ARE, NF-κB signaling, and autophagy pathways. Two mutations in the KIR domain (P348L and G351A) result in the failure of p62 binding to Keap1, which further fails to activate Nrf2 and fight oxidative stress.(155) Both Keap1–Nrf2 signaling and oxidative stress have been observed in the post mortem tissues from ALS/FTD patients.(156) p62 regulates the NF-κB signaling pathway via its PB1 and TB domain. Several mutations in the two domains have been identified in ALS/FTD patients, which indicates that defective NF-κB signaling might be a possible cause of ALS/FTD.(150) Two mutations in the LIR domain (D337E and L341V) are associated with ALS/FTD, contributing to the failure of p62 interacting with LC3 and autophagic degradation.(150)

    6. p62 and Atherosclerosis (AS)

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Atherosclerosis (AS), characterized by excessive cholesterol deposition and lipid accumulation, is the main cause of coronary heart disease, cerebral infarction, and peripheral vascular disease.(157) There are three main proposed mechanisms suggested in AS pathology: dampened inflammasome/IL-1b activation, accelerated removal of protein aggregates, and particularly increased cholesterol efflux, which has become a hot spot in the research study in recent years.(158) Dyslipidemia, characterized by excessive cholesterol deposition and low concentration of high-density lipoprotein, makes AS a serious public health problem, resulting in thrombus formation, myocardial infarction, stroke, and sudden cardiac death.(159) Even though various AS onset hypotheses have been proposed, unequivocal curative treatments are still not available. In AS animal models, we can find that the level of p62 expression is higher than the corresponding controls.(159) The phenomenon activates us to discuss the relationship between p62 protein and AS.

    6.1. p62 as an AS Activator

    A growing body of evidence has demonstrated the important role of selective autophagy in AS. The disruption of macrophage autophagy in mice (Atg5–/–) leads to an obvious increase of cholesterol crystals, the hallmark of atherosclerotic plaques, indicating the occurrence of AS.(158) Autophagy plays a protective role of in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) via degrading damaged intracellular proteins, especially dysfunctional mitochondria.(160) The dysfunction of autophagy in AS causes a vicious circle, where damaged materials are unable to be cleared and lead to further autophagy inhibition. p62 was observed at a high level in macrophage-rich areas of atherosclerotic aortas detected by Western blotting, consistent with autophagy dysfunction. In fact, the formation of p62-enriched polyubiquitinated aggregates has become a novel hallmark of the deficient autophagy in advancing atherosclerotic plaques.(161) Therefore, we can propose a hypothesis that the abnormal increase of p62 expression may be a feature of atherosclerotic plaques under autophagy-deficient conditions and positively correlated with the progression of AS. Previous experiments have shown that the knockdown of p62 could inhibit the formation of lipid-laden foam cells and improve autophagic activity leading to increased reversal cholesterol transportation(157) and lowering lipid deposition. Both lipid-laden foam cells and excessive lipid deposition can facilitate the development and deterioration of AS in lesion plaques.

    6.2. Possible Atheroprotective Methods

    Because of the positive relationship between the p62 level and AS, it is a potential method to treat AS by down-regulating p62 expression or enhancing autophagic activity. Autophagy normally plays a critical role in preventing the formation and development of lipid-filled foam cells in the early stage of AS. Here are three available instances of activating autophagy and inhibiting p62 to reduce AS: trehalose, green tea polyphenol (GTP), and rapamycin. Trehalose, the nonreducing natural disaccharide, has been reported as an available autophagy inducer in vivo and functions as an atheroprotective role through regulating autophagy and p62.(161) Trehalose promotes the autophagy degradative property by inducing macrophage autophagy-lysosomal biogenesis and simulating the atheroprotective activity of macrophage TFEB overexpression, which is a dominating transcriptional activating factor of linking autophagy to lysosomal biogenesis.(162) Trehalose up-regulates the activity of the autophagy-lysosome system in macrophages to achieve the objective of protecting VSMCs from AS through increased protein aggregate clearance, reduced apoptosis, and reduced IL-1B production.(163) In summary, trehalose-driven atheroprotection is autophagy- and p62-dependent. It is worth mentioning that despite trehalose as a treatment for cardiovascular disease, atheroprotection has not been observed by oral administration only, but intraperitoneal administration exhibits a stable level. This reminds us that further animal experiments of trehalose evaluations should consider the method of administration. GTP, a type of flavonoid, is a polyphenol source from green tea. Consisting of epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) and catechin primarily, GTP has called widespread attention for its effect on preventing cardiovascular diseases.(159) GTP inhibits atherogenesis through improving the autophagy flux in the vessel wall of apolipoprotein E-knockout mice (ApoE-knockout mice, an animal model of AS) as well as directly inhibiting the level of oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL), which induces p62 accumulation in macrophage-rich areas of atherosclerotic aortas.(158) Moreover, GTP has other beneficial effects on atheroprotection, such as antioxidant function and regulation of lipid metabolism. The mechanism of GTP functioning indicates that the combined action of up-regulating autophagy to promote lipid metabolism and decreasing lipid droplets in endothelial cells may be more effective in atheroprotection than a single pathway. This suggests that a multitarget interaction is superior to a single target. Rapamycin is a well-known inhibitor of autophagy and has been reported to play a potential role in treating AS.(164) The mTOR pathway enhances foam cell formation by dampening autophagy activation and could be activated during foam cell formation in turn. Silencing mTOR expression is an available therapy to slow down the initiation and progression of AS and complications by inhibiting foam cells and activating autophagy to promote reverse cholesterol transport. To sum up, up-regulating autophagy and inhibiting p62 overexpression may provide a novel strategy against AS.

    6.3. Differences between AS and AD

    By comparing AS and AD, aberrant protein aggregation is a common pathogenic feature. Misfolded protein accumulation is discovered in both damaged neurons(115) and atherosclerotic plaques.(165) It is evident that degrading insoluble protein aggregates is an effective approach to prevent the cell from cytotoxicity and apoptosis in various autophagy-associated diseases. It is worth noting that p62 serves diverse functions in these two diseases. p62 overexpression is a severe issue and should be degraded in advancing atherosclerotic plaques, while the up-regulation of p62 is expected to delay the AD process. Different impacts of autophagy on AS and AD may account for this contradictory phenomenon. The correlation between autophagy dysfunction and AS is explicit: autophagic activity in macrophages is inhibited by exorbitant lipid deposition, and p62 as an autophagy substrate is above the normal level. Therefore, the main duty of atheroprotection is to activate autophagy to degrade redundant p62 and other detrimental protein aggregates. Autophagy inducers or p62 inhibitors like resveratrol and XRK3F2 have been reported.(166) Nevertheless, the relationship between autophagy and AD is complicated, even controversial. Some researchers believe that the mitophagy system is damaged in AD and mitophagy-inducing compounds such as rapamycin, urolithins,(167) and spermidine(168) may be possible methods of AD treatment. On the contrary, Dai et al. discovered that mitophagy is increased caused by Parkin depletion,(169) and excessive mitophagy leads to synaptic deterioration and axon degeneration.(170) Even so, p62 is distinctly decreased in different stages of neurodegeneration; it is a feasible and promising way to up-regulate p62 expression to delay AD development.

    7. p62 and Paget’s Disease of Bone (PDB)

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Paget’s disease of bone (PDB) is the second most common bone disease resulting in serious bone deformity and structural weakness, which influences about 2–3% of the population over 60 years old.(78) This disease was first discovered by Sir James Paget who described detailed symptoms after studying the clinical history and post-mortem findings in 1876; hence, the bone disorder was referred to as “Paget’s disease of bone”.(171)

    7.1. Mechanisms of PDB

    PDB has an autosomal dominant feature with genetic heterogeneity, characterized by highly localized areas of abnormal and excessive bone turnover, especially increased bone resorption accompanied by bone formation disorders with vigorous but aberrant osteoclasts (OCLs) activity.(172) Normal physiological function of bone depends on the precise balance between formation and resorption controlled by osteoblasts (OBLs) and OCLs. Abnormality of OCL activity is an essential factor for focal bone lesions and PDB genesis. Multiple influencing elements of PDB via inducting OCLs overexpression have been put forward: inheritance, environmental factors, and gene mutations. Moreover, familial clustering is often observed in this lesion, with between 15 and 40% of patients having at least one affected first-degree relative.(173) In spite of various elements involved in PDB genesis and evolution, the exact mechanism remains unclear currently. There is an intriguing hypothesis considering that somatic mutations in bone cells may contribute to the pathogenesis of pagetic lesions,(174) similar to somatic mutations in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes do in tumorigenesis.(175)

    7.2. p62P392L Mutation

    Hitherto, the only uncovered gene with mutations in the coding region linked to PDB is SQSTM1, which encodes the p62 protein, as mentioned before. Recurrent mutations lying in the UBA domain have been identified in about 25% of familial and less than 10% of sporadic cases. To explore the role of p62 mutation in PDB, predecessors have generated mice harboring a mutation causing a proline-to-leucine (P-to-L) substitution at residue 394 (the murine equivalent of human p62P392L, the most common mutation in PDB). Subsequent results demonstrated that despite the enhanced osteoclastogenic potential of both bone marrow stromal cells and OCL precursors, which developed progressive osteopenia, in p62P394L knock-in mice, these transgenic mice had histologically normal bones without pagetic bone lesions.(175) Obviously, expression of the p62 predisposing mutation (p62P392L) contributes to increased OCLs activity by enhancing the capacity of associated cells or signaling pathways to support osteoclastogenesis as well as to increase new bone formation.
    The primary cellular defect in PDB is generally thought to reside in large numbers of hyper-multinucleated OCLs; increased OCL formation and resorption play a major pathogenic role in the undesirable bone changes, and suppression of OCL activity in PDB patients results in prolonged clinical and histological remissions. On the other hand, the p62P392L mutation is widely associated with OCL differentiation and eventually leads to increased OCL activity, common in PDB. Therefore, it is necessary to explore and reveal the mechanisms of p62P392L, stimulating OCL differentiation in PDB in vivo. p62P392L transduced OCL precursors exhibit higher sensitivity to the osteoclastogenic cytokines receptor activator of the NF-κB ligand (RANKL) and TNF-α than analogous bone marrow cultures in wild-type mice.(176) Both RANKL and TNF-α activate signaling pathways involving p62 that ultimately lead to the activation of NF-κB, p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), and extracellular regulated protein kinases 1/2 (ERK1/2), which are important for OCL formation and function. The effects of RANKL on OCL differentiation are mediated by downstream effector molecules, which lead to OCL-specific gene expression. RANKL also promotes OCL survival and participation by stimulating MAPK pathways in new cycles of bone degradation.(177) OCLs are large multinucleated cells formed through the fusion of precursors of the monocyte–macrophage lineage in response to RANKL stimulation. p62P392L mutation is involved in the RANK signaling pathway through activating the transcription factors including activator protein 1 (AP-1) and NF-κB.(178) Besides increasing NF-κB activity via IL-1, TNF, and NGF, p62 also links TRAF6 with aPKCs to activate RANKL (Figure 8).
    However, it is controversial whether p62P394L mutation in transgenic mice (equivalent to human p62P392L)(78) alone is sufficient to cause a PDB-like disorder or pagetic bone lesions. Kurihara et al. pointed out that the osteoclastogenic potential of both OCL precursors and the marrow microenvironment are increased via p62P394L mutation in knock-in mice models, but these changes caused by p62P394L mutation alone are not sufficient to create the full paget-like phenotype or induce bone lesions.(179) This suggests that other genetic and environmental factors, such as paramyxoviruses, acting together with gene mutation, are also necessary for the development of PDB in vivo. On the contrary, Daroszewska et al. claimed that P394L mutation in the UBA domain was sufficient to cause a PDB-like disorder in mice,(180) but agreed with the opinion that environmental factors might also affect the severity and extent of PDB. The two conflicting results may attribute to different evaluation methods. On the whole, p62P394L mutation is the root cause for PDB genesis, while environmental factors are conducive to advancing PDB in mice.

    7.3. Possible Therapeutic Methods

    To date, there are two main methods to treat PDB clinically: medical management and surgical operations. Bisphosphonates, as antiresorptive agents, are the first choice for PDB treatment through inhibiting bone resorption specifically.(181) However, side effects, including hypocalcemia,(182) renal impairment, and osteonecrosis,(183) are observed clinically after taking bisphosphonates such as alendronate, pamidronate, etc. Since human p62P392L mutation is the primary cause of PDB, it is an evolvable approach to use genetic testing and target intervention techniques for patients with p62P392L mutation fundamentally. Better effects may be received by combination with inhibitors of the RANKL–RANK–NF-κB pathway for its critical adjusting action in OCL formation and differentiation.(184)

    8. Small Molecular Modulators of p62

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    p62 is suggested to be a potential target for its close interaction with autophagy and Nrf2 regulation. This adaptor protein is detected to be abnormally expressed in various diseases as mentioned before. It is meaningful to design and exploit small molecular inhibitors and activators of p62 to alleviate disease symptoms. Although, there are still no drugs that regulate p62 on the market, some reported small molecules might be noteworthy. Several compounds influencing p62 expression have been reported by previous researchers. However, there are few small molecular drugs directly acting on p62, most influencing its level through other targets. Table 1 enumerates reported different types of p62 molecular modulators.
    Table 1. Reported Compounds Affected p62 Expression
    XRK3F2 is a specific ZZ-domain of the p62 inhibitor that inhibits multiple myeloma (MM) with an IC50 of 4.6 μM in the human MM cell line.(166) Ripasudil (K-115) is a selective ROCK inhibitor and regulates the expression of p62 in TNF-induced neurodegeneration, with IC50 values of 19 and 51 nM against ROCK2 and ROCK1, respectively.(185) Both NMS-E973 and BIIB021 are selective heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) inhibitors, which induce autophagy to degrade p62. NMS-E973 showed a DC50 less than 10 nM for Hsp90 binding,(186) and BIIB021 is an orally available inhibitor of Hsp90 with Ki of 1.7 nM.(187) K67 is an inhibitor for the Keap1-phosphorylated-p62 (p-p62) protein–protein interaction (PPI) reported by Daisuke Yasuda et al. K67 promotes superfluous Nrf2 degradation by inhibiting the interaction between p-p62 and Keap1 with an IC50 value of 1.5 μM, resulting in the suppression of tumorigenesis and anticancer drug resistance of HCC.(188) Tsuganezawa et al. utilized two-colored fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS) to screen for LC3–p62 interaction inhibitors. They achieved two selected inhibitors with IC50 values less than 2 μM: compound 1 and compound 2.(189) Sulfasalazine (SAS) is a classic inhibitor of NF-κB. SAS that can induce p62 expression may be due to promoting its degradation by autophagy.(190) Rapamycin and Everolimus are mTOR inhibitors and induce the autophagic activity to degrade p62. Rapamycin showed an IC50 of 0.1 nM in HEK293 cells,(191) and Everolimus showed an IC50 of 5–6 nM.(192) Dactolisib (NVP-BEZ235) is a dual ATP competitive inhibitor of PI3K and mTOR, with an IC50 of 20.7 nM for mTOR, which can also cause changes in the expression level of LC3 and p62.(193) Licochalcone A (LCA) is an autophagosome inducer, which can induce the increase of intracellular acidic autophagy vesicles and autophagosomes. The IC50 value is 0.97 μM for UGT1A1. It can obviously induce LC3-II, beclin 1, and Atg5 protein expression, but reduce p62 protein expression, as well as mTOR phosphorylation.(194) Resveratrol is a natural plant antitoxin with anticancer and anti-inflammatory properties, which could induce p62 expression by activating autophagy. The IC50 value is 3.3 μM for DNA polymerase α.(195) ABT-751(E 7010) is a new biocompatible microtubulin binding agent and mitoid-resistant sulfonamide compound to promote autophagy and inhibit p62, with an IC50 of 1.5 μM in neuroblastoma cell lines.(196) Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), as an important endogenous steroid hormone, is an androgen receptor antagonist and estrogen receptor agonist. DHEA prevents linoleic acid (LA)-induced endothelial senescence by increasing the ratio of LC3-II and decreasing the level of p62 in a time- and dose-dependent manner.(197) (1S,3R)-RSL3 and ML-162 are two inhibitors of glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4), which induces the hypertrophic death of head and neck cancer (HNC) cells. In HN3-resistant (HN3-rslR) cells, (1S,3R)-RSL3 or ML-162 treatment increased expression levels of p62 and Nrf2 through inactivation of Keap1.(198) ML-162 and (1S,3R)-RSL3 are structurally similar, but ML-162 is more potent and selective. (1S,3R)-RSL3 showed an IC50 of 5.8 μM in HN3-rslR cells.(198) ML-162 showed an IC50 of 25 nM in mutant RAS oncogene-expressing cell lines.(199) Vps34-PIK-III is a selective inhibitor of an ATP competitive vacuolar protein sorting 34 (VPS34) with an IC50 of 18 nM and blocks autophagy, resulting in the increase of LC3-I levels and the stabilization of autophagy substrates including p62.(200) VPS34 inhibitor 3 is a PIK-III analogue with an IC50 of 15 nM and owns a higher inhibitory effect of VPS34.(201) Autophinib is a selective autophagy inhibitor with an IC50 of 90 nM or 40 nM for starvation- or rapamycin-induced autophagy, respectively. Besides, Autophinib is also a VPS34 inhibitor with an IC50 of 19 nM. Autophinib inhibits p62 degradation via inhibition of starvation- or rapamycin-induced autophagy by targeting VPS34 in MCF7-LC3 cells.(202) PF-4708671 is a potent cell-permeable p70 ribosomal S6 kinase 1 (S6K1) inhibitor with a Ki of 20 nM and IC50 of 160 nM. S6K1 functions to regulate protein synthesis and cell growth downstream of the mTOR protein kinase.(203) The absence of S6K1 is accompanied by the formation of p62-positive protein aggregates in muscle hypertrophy.(204) 3-Methyladenine (3-MA) is a PI3K inhibitor and widely used as a depressor of autophagy via inhibiting class III PI3K. Treatment with 3-MA causes a significant increase in p62 expression by blocking the formation of autophagosomes.(205) Verteporfin is a photosensitizer for photodynamic therapy to eliminate the abnormal blood vessels in the eye associated with conditions such as age-related macular degeneration. Verteporfin is identified as a YAP inhibitor by disrupting YAP–TEAD interactions. Additionally, Verteporfin is also an inhibitor of autophagosome by promoting oligomerization of p62 and proves to be tumor-selective proteotoxic in colorectal cancer. The GI50 value is 228 nM in PhLO cells.(206) Aloxistatin (E64d) is an irreversible membrane-permeable and broad-spectrum cysteine protease inhibitor, which has an inhibitory effect on inhibiting platelet aggregation. E64d attenuates the proliferation of the parathyroid hormone-induced cell in vitro and inhibits osteoblast differentiation. The expression of p62 is significantly enhanced by treatment with E64d.(207) Dorsomorphin (BML-275) is a selective and cell-permeable AMPK inhibitor by competing with ATP, with a Ki of 109 nM in the absence of AMP.(208) BML-275 can promote p62 expression and reduce the levels of LC3 and p-AMPK by inhibiting estrogen-induced cell autophagy. Cycloheximide (CHX) is an inhibitor of eukaryotic protein synthesis, and the IC50 value of inhibiting protein synthesis is 532.5 nM in vivo.(209) Nrf2 is activated through up-regulating p62 after treatment with CHX. Proadifen hydrochloride (SKF-525A) is a cytochrome P450 (CYP) inhibitor with an IC50 of 19 μM and promotes p62 expression.(210) Chloroquine (CQ) is an autophagy and toll-like receptors (TLRs) inhibitor, which can induce the expression of p62 by inhibiting autophagic flux.(211)

    9. Discussion and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Based on the above descriptions, p62 is suggested to be a potential target profiting by its close interaction with selective autophagy and Nrf2 regulation. This adaptor protein distributes in organs and tissues throughout the whole body. In other words, p62 is a universal regulatory protein in vivo. When autophagy is inhibited or cells undergo oxidative stress, the expression level of p62 is detected to be abnormal in various disease processes as mentioned before. Since its aberrant expression in illnesses, p62 can be considered as a clinical diagnostic marker for several disorders. The quantitative analysis technique of p62 should be put forward because p62 can serve as a pathological indicator. It has been expected to be a good prognostic marker for HCC and ovarian cancer. On the other hand, disease symptoms are expected to be attenuated even reversed by reregulating p62 levels. p62 accumulation, as a pathological characteristic, could act as a novel diagnostic sign and prognostic marker. p62 accumulation is frequently combined with autophagy deficiency, leading to misfolded protein aggregation, which is the significant factor of disease occurrence and development. The level of autophagy flux can be evaluated by detecting the p62 expression, and the p62 level inversely correlates with the activity of autophagy. In a manner of speaking, p62 accumulation is the reflection of autophagy dysfunction for that p62 is an autophagy substrate and can be selectively degraded. It is beneficial for symptomatic improvement by reducing the accumulation of p62 and recovering the regular degradation function of autophagy. Taken together, it is a credible corollary that p62 as a latent target is effective and feasible in the territory of disease diagnosis and treatment.
    In different diseases, p62 serves disparate functions, and the regulation of p62 should depend on the specific circumstances. Applying p62 to PDB treatment might be more effective compared to other traditional therapies. There are still no cure therapies for PDB currently, and the goals of treatment are to relieve pain, rectify bending deformities, and stabilize pathological fractures. p62P392L mutation is the root cause of sporadic PDB lesions. Therefore, it may be a novel therapeutic method to knock out this gene prone to mutation and solve the problem fundamentally. p62 plays a dual role in regulating tumorigenesis: it is observed to be overexpressed in tumor epithelium, while deficient in tumor stroma fibroblasts, especially in CAFs. The double impacts remind us to pay attention to the tumor tissue selectivity and pharmacy boundaries when regulating p62 expression. It is necessary to establish the standard of the p62 normal expression level, which can provide a basis for the selection of inhibitors and activators in the future. Combination drug therapy between p62 inhibitors and autophagy activators acquires a favorable curative effect in tumor metastasis. In AD, p62 is detected to be deficient, and up-regulating the expression of this protein is advantageous to slow disease progression. Therefore, the activators of p62 are requisite in this process. Compared to cancer, drugs for AD develop slowly and are blocked frequently, which makes it imperative for researchers to search for new therapeutic targets. p62 deficiency is a typical characteristic in AD, and this potential target needs enough attention. When designing p62 activators, it is imperative to take the perviousness of the blood–brain barrier (BBB) into consideration. AD is a severe neurodegenerative disorder with complex mechanisms and plenty of influencing factors. It is not enough to merely up-regulate p62 expression. There are also urgent issues demanding solutions like elevating the ability of antioxidative stress and promoting the clearance of Aβ deposition and NFTs. It is a promising and hopefully usable method to design multitarget drugs and conduct drug combination in AD therapies.
    Although p62 plays unique roles in physical or pathological processes, the loss of p62 is actually not lethal. The p62–/– mice are viable, but the lifespan is shorter than wild-type controls.(212) In humans, the loss of p62 caused damages to the central nervous system without other organs affected.(139,213) To some extent, it reflects the safety of p62 as a therapeutic target. There may be differences between the acute and chronic modulation of p62. A few kinds of research focused on the acute modulation of p62, but the chronic absence of p62 tends to have many negative impacts. Mice deficient of p62 displayed mature-onset obesity, leptin resistance, as well as insulin resistance.(214) The chronic absence of p62 in individuals showed significantly increased levels of phosphorylated tau and caused childhood-onset neurodegeneration.(215)
    Nevertheless, there are still no marketed drugs targeting p62 as a therapeutic strategy currently. It has broad research prospects of research and application to design and synthesize small molecular inhibitors and activators of p62. Besides molecules working directly on p62, exploiting PPI inhibitors between p62 and other binding proteins is also feasible and indispensable because that p62 plays its unique roles in regulating autophagy and Nrf2 expression via these pivotal binding proteins such as LC3 and Keap1. In addition, the wide distribution of p62 indicates its universality, while it also brings up a pressing problem: tissue selectivity and targeting of p62. Choosing appropriate drug carriers or developing new dosage forms may be conducive to p62 regulators reaching the lesions accurately. Selectivity is required not only for drug use in tissues but also for the design of p62-related preparations in specific regions. When designing small molecules of p62, domain selection should be taken into consideration because p62 has six domains with different functions. For example, blocking the ubiquitination process needs to act on the UBA domain. To restrain the self-oligomerization of p62, the PB1 domain should be inhibited. To regulate the Nrf2 pathway to enhance the ability against oxidative stress, it is effective to directly activate the KIR of p62. It is necessary to design novel selective preparations for different domains based on therapeutic purposes. Depending on the structural differences of the cavity of domains, it is a feasible method to discover novel selective p62 regulators by using computer-aided drug design (CADD) techniques.
    Even so, there are still many unresolved issues in mechanisms of p62 functions. For instance, although the relationship between autophagy and p62 as an adaptor protein has been manifested, how p62 distinguishes or recognizes “cargoes” between conventional versus selective autophagy is still worth further research. As previously mentioned, p62 expression imbalance is just a pathological feature in certain circumstances instead of the primary cause of disease occurrence. The inherent mechanisms of p62 impacting AD, AS, and tumorigenesis processes require more and deeper exploration in the future. Similarly, the therapeutic effect via regulating p62 deserves further discussion and explanation. In terms of discovery and druggability, the demand for selectivity and targeting is very high on account of p62 extensive distribution and diversity of domains, which raises the difficulty level for drug design.

    10. Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    p62/SQSTM1 is an acknowledged autophagy substrate whose expression quantity reflects the level of autophagic activity. With further understanding of this protein, p62 has been reported to function as a significant signaling hub in regulating several important pathways, especially in the proteolytic system and the Nrf2 pathway. The expression of this adaptor protein is observably abnormal in tumorigenesis, neurodegeneration, AS, and PDB as mentioned before. Additionally, researchers also found that adverse symptoms can be ameliorated by regulating p62 expression in HD(216) and AS(159) model mice. Considering these two points, p62 is suggested to be a novel latent target for disease diagnosis and treatment in tumorigenesis, neurodegeneration, AS, and PDB. Up to date, there are few drugs acting on p62 on the market. It is promising to design and exploit more effective small molecular drugs or PPI inhibitors for this potential and valuable target. Although we have understood the relationships between p62, autophagy, and these diseases, the mechanisms of how this protein realize its functions require further exploration and investigation.
